metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
AIR MAIL COPY
ZANDER [and] COMPANY. INC.
413-417 GRAVIER STREET
NEW ORLEANS, LA.
Feb 24 th 1943.
Lt. S.J.Legendre,
Box 166 Navy Yard,
Pearl Harbor, T.H.
Dear Sid-
I'm sending this in duplicete- one air-mail end one regular-- to be sure you
get et least one copy , as I gather from some of your remarks that some of my letters
might heve gone astray.
I got your air-mail letter of the Feb 15 last night. I hevent written you since
I talked to you onthe phone on Sunday Feb 14 , as each day I figured I would be
hearing from you. I was just about to write you yesterday when your letter arrived.
It sure was welcome because I was beginning to think something had gone wrong. Whilst
I havent heard anything from Washington as yet, I'm sure everything should be okay
unless the big shot doesnt like my record when you checks it over. It is nothing to be
proud of! It will show thet I started off on the Suwannee as "1St Lt." and after a
month or so I was supplented by a Lt Comdr. who arrived by plane--- I imagine at the
urgent request of our Captain ! I was then made " 1 st Division " officer, under the
Gunnery Officer, and I was not the Gunnery Officer, as you state in your memorandum.
I mention this because if Washington calls this to your boss's attention , you can
advise his that this was unknown to you.
There are a few other discrepencies in your memo which I dont think are
important but nevertheless think I had better mention them in case of any "come-back".
I was born June 17 1899 [not 1898]
I was not All-American-but on Camps second team[Bob Phillips always said
this was an "undue technicelity!"] I especially mention this as if
your commading officer is a demon on memory, he will know thet I was
not an All-American and may think we ere trying to pull a "fast one".
I am not working in the Personell office here but in "Office of Naval
Officer Procurement". It is of course under the Bureau of Personnell.
I had a "B.A," degree from Princeton--not a "B.S."
Now here is the only point I consider important.
You state in "5"-- "knee is now stiff and he has been advised further
sea duty is not possible". If I wrote you that, I was wrong. Of course
you may have access to some confidential files that I dont know about,
and in which I have been declared unfit for sea duty. If so, I myself
have never been so advised. Here is the story as far as I know it-
When I returned to the Norfolk Hospital Jan 14[ a day or so after
talking to you on the phone from Gerties] I told the Dr that if I couldnt
go to sea fro a month or so, I would like to go to a training school and
that if he would discherge me from the hospital, I thought I could get
someone in the Personnel office in Washington to send me to a school.
The Dr said that I wasnt ready for xxxxxx sea yet but that he wasnt
[End Page 1]
AIR MAIL COPY
ZANDER [and] COMPANY. INC.
413-417 GRAVIER STREET
NEW ORLEANS, LA.
permitted to give me a discharge from the hospital to the effect that I was fit
xxxxxxxxxonly to go to a school. He would either have to give me a full dischare or
nothing-and of course I would have to take my chance of being sent directly to sea.
I said I would take my chances. So he discharged me. But then instead of sending me
to a school, the guy in Washington sent me home on two weeks leave with orders to
report to Com 8 in New Orleans on Feb 12 for "temporary duty pending further assignment
by the Bureau". In the meatime the Procurement Office big shot had heard I was on
town and he wired Washington asking for me and I was then assigned to that office and
that where I am now.
Now whether Washington intended to leave me in Procurement or send me to sea as
soon as they thought my knee could take it, I of course cant tell. My own hunch is
that the Guy in Washington thought I was too dam old to go to a school but he was
nice enough not to send me right back to sea as he had seen my knee and I guess he
knew that I couldnt take it yet. On the other handsxxx he may have had some correspondence
with the hospital--of which I know nothing-- and has decided that I'm worthless for
further sea duty.
The reason I go into all this lenghthy explanation is because your statement
about my being 'unfit' may think I'm trying to shirk sea duty. Frankly I dont think
this knee will stand sea duty in its present condition and I cant tell how long it will
be before it is okay. It is not getting strong very fast. It did the first part of
the actual healing swell but the rebuilding of the muscles is coming along pretty
slow. I can walk plenty far but I cant run or turn sharp corners or go up and donw
ladders without It hurting. It lent "stiff"--quite the contrary, it wobbles all over
the dam place! I'm in hopes that If I get out with you guys and get some good sun
and swimming, that it will get okay In a hurry. Then if they want to send me back to
the Suwannee or anything else It okey doke by me, although if its as wonderfull as you
say , I'll probably fight and scream if they try and tear me away!
Well so much for all that-- now let me tell you how much I appreciate all the
work you have dons to help me get there. I really cant think of anything I would
rather do than be with you. I never even thought of it last spring or summer because
I didnt think such a thing could be possible. Frankly I had "such little faith" in
our Fuhrer that I dindt think he could keep even the two of you together. Of course
I am now a "convert" to the Fuhrer and realize that absolutely nothing is impossible
for him to accomplish. Seriously though, you guys must have done a swell job out there
to have gotten so much drag with you Commanding Officer. Congratulations!
Perhaps you re thinking that I as foolish to even want to once again stray
away from N O and leqve Olive and the children. I am doing it will Olives full consent.
It so happens that there is one type of duty I dont crave in the Navy[I mean besides
Procurement! ] and there is a certain Capt that is trying to get me under xx his
commnad. Olive figures that "of the two evils" she prefers ny being with you two!
[End Page 2]
AIR MAIL COPY
ZANDER [and] COMPANY. INC.
413-417 GRAVIER STREET
NEW ORLEANS, LA.
Page [number]3
Thanks for all the infomation regarding clothes needed. However I think I will
bring all the Navy clothes that I have because some fine day they may transfer me to
the Aleutians or Siberia.
I am trying not to count too much on everything going thru okay, so that if
anything goes wrong I wont be too dissapointed. I sure have ny fingers crossed and
each morning when I go to that dam Procurement office I rush thru the mail looking
for "orders". But If something does go wrong, please let me know as soon as
possible, as I have something else I want to get started working on. Its nothing
as swell as your proposition but it is an improvement over Procurement. By the way--
who do you think is my immediate superior at Procurement ? None other than Nat!
I got back at him the other day however by taking him out on a P.C. boat and letting
him fall down a few hatches.
By the way--just so you wont think you are foisting a "cripple" on your
Commanding Officer, let me haste to reassure you that this knee doesnt hinder my
working in the least--just so I'm not expected to run! Outside of the knee I an
In fine shape and can drink almost two whiskeys without passing out.
As soon as I hear something definite I will write you. I dont guess there is
any use in my cabling because I understand my last cable never reached you.
Well so long guys--I sure have my fingers crossed- and thanks again for all your
trouble
Arma
[End Page 3]
